Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Master closes his pocket-watch sized device and presses a button on its lid.
A portal in the wall lifts slightly and gas pours in.

Dialogue.Line: Doctor, please hurry up. The Master might come back.
I'm coming, Jo, I'm coming. Jo, you're standing in the alarm beam!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Jo steps forward and the doors close.

Dialogue.Line: Doctor, I can't breathe!
Gas!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: They both collapse.
Ashe shows the Master a map.

Dialogue.Line: This is the area surrounding the Primitive city.
But you have no map of the city itself?
We never go there. It's too dangerous.
So really, nobody knows exactly what's in there?
Oh, yes, the Doctor does.
Why did he go there?
He went to get Jo Grant. The Primitives had taken her. Shall I go and get him for you?
No, no, that won't be necessary. I think I know where he is.
Keep main retro rockets steady.
Thirty metres. Descent rate at minimum.
Activate landing stabilisers.
Landing stabilisers in position.
Report on altitude.
Twenty metres. Fifteen metres. Ten, nine, eight, seven, six, five, three, one. We have contact.
Cut motors. Send in the security guard leaders. We have no time to waste.
Suppose the colonists are waiting for you?
They won't be.
They could have seen us come down.
Impossible. We've landed on the other side of a range of hills.
That's why we landed here.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Three security guards enter.

Dialogue.Line: We have landed approximately fifty kilometres from the colonists' main dome.
We can be there is two and a half hours. It'll be dark by then.
Thank you, Morgan. You have been defeated and disarmed by a group of farmers. Now is your chance to wipe out this black mark on your records.
That's very inspiring.
Your reputation's at stake as well, Caldwell. Our objective is a simple one. To avenge our humiliation and put paid to these colonists.
But just remember, they've got the guns.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Master puts an oxygen mask on the Doctor and he wakes.

Dialogue.Line: Well, Doctor, still pursuing burglary, eh? You know, when you stole my dematerialisation circuit, I decided to build in a few precautions.
What have you done, what have you done to her this time?
The same as I did to you. A simple sleep gas. Mind you, I could just have easily used a lethal one.
What stopped you?
I want to use your services as a guide, Doctor. You're going to take me to the Primitive city.
What do you want there?
That's no concern of yours. But you will do what I ask?
I take it that Miss Grant is to be held here as a hostage. You know, you really are most unimaginative.
Ah, tried and true methods are the best. Well, Doctor?
Where's the Adjudicator? It's time we sent him back to Earth.
I don't know.
Where is he, Ashe?
I think he went to see the Doctor.
There's no sign of either of them. Now what are they up to?
Oh, perhaps they went to the Adjudicator's spaceship.
I've just radioed to it and there's no reply. When are you going to issue these IMC guns to our people?
I'm not.
I want these guns issued, Ashe.
Those monsters were faked and the IMC men have gone. Those are military weapons. We don't need them.
What if the Earth government send troops?
If the Adjudicator helps us, it should never come to that.
Very well. I'll go and check up on the guards.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Winton catches the night sentries not paying attention.

Dialogue.Line: Yes, well, try not to nod off altogether. We've still got the Primitives to worry about, you know.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Winton leaves.

Dialogue.Line: You worry too much, Winton.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Behind his back, the other guard is grabbed and dragged away.

Dialogue.Line: Tony? Tony?

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Morgan knocks him out. He waits outside while two colonists cross the entry area then goes in with another of his men and duck behind the staircase and go round the back to -

Dialogue.Line: How did you? Why have you come back here?
To reclaim our property.
You're to leave those where they are!
Get them!
What are you going to do?
You'll find out. Cover him.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Morgan signals for Dent and the other two IMC men to come through.
Winton finds the second guard on the ground.

Dialogue.Line: Guards, over here, quick!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Morgan takes an automatic weapon from the collection.

Dialogue.Line: Come with me.

Dialogue.Character: (Morgan leaves with one man. The other two take weapons and go into the radio shack. A gun battle starts with the colonists outside.) DENT
Dialogue.Line: Get up!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Dent uses Ashe as a human shield.

Dialogue.Line: Hold your fire!
If you want your leader alive, drop your guns!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The colonists obey.

Dialogue.Line: And you said we didn't need those guns, Ashe.
Well done.
It was a pleasure.
Make sure the rest of the dome is secure. Round up any strays and take their guns. Take good care of him. We must have him fit for the trial.
Trial? What trial?
And what are you going to charge us with, trespass?
No, treason.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Doctor and Jo are held prisoners in a pair of large perspex tubes. The Master gets his laser gun from the console and releases the Doctor.

Dialogue.Line: I'm sorry to have kept you waiting, Doctor, but it's light now. We can set off. Doctor, let me show you this.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: It's his pocket-watch device.

Dialogue.Line: I just have to press this button on here, and Miss Grant's cubicle will immediately be flooded with lethal gas.
You realise, of course, it can be extremely dangerous taking you to the Primitive city?
Don't worry about my welfare, Doctor. Keep thinking of Miss Grant's.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Unnoticed by the Master, the Doctor drops the Tardis key on the ground.

Dialogue.Line: Right, Doctor, the buggy is over there.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: A table has been brought out, and a water carafe is on it. Ashe and Winton are in handcuffs.

Dialogue.Line: As legally appointed Governor of this planet, I declare this court in session. Morgan?

You are charged with destroying property and equipment belonging to the Interplanetary Mining Corporation, assault and murder of IMC personnel, trespass on a planet lawfully allocated to IMC, and armed rebellion against the lawful representatives of the Earth's government. How do you plead?
This whole business is a joke!
I advise you to take it very seriously. Have you anything to say in your own defence?
Everything we've done has been provoked by you. This planet is rightfully ours!
The only mistake we made was not killing you when we had the chance.
You will do yourself no good by this hostile attitude, nor by repeating slanderous allegations which have already been dismissed by the Adjudicator.
Why isn't the Adjudicator taking this trial? What right have you to sit

You still don't realise the position, Ashe. The Adjudicator's authority passed to me when he made his decision. I am now the legal ruler of this planet. Now for the last time, have you anything to say?
I agree with Winton. This trial is a farce.
I take it you admit the charges?
We've admitted nothing.

On three of these charges, you could be sentenced to life imprisonment. On two you could be sentenced to death. The sentence is execution. However, the sentence will be suspended on condition that you and your followers depart this planet immediately.
But that's impossible!
The alternative is execution.
You don't understand. That spaceship was old when we bought it. It won't survive another trip.
The trial is now concluded.
If you send us up in that spaceship, you're condemning all of us to death.
You will make preparations for lift off immediately.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Doctor drives a buggy at great speed along a track. Up on a cliff, a Primitive signals that they are approaching. Two others return his signal. The Doctor stops in front of a pipe across the track.

Dialogue.Line: Yeah, well, you stay there. I'll go and shift that irrigation pipe.
Doctor? I hope you're not going to try anything clever. Remember Miss Grant.
I'll remember. Look out!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The two Primitives have sent a large boulder rolling down a gully towards the buggy. The Master gets out before it is tipped over.

Dialogue.Line: Don't forget that you're still my prisoner.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Doctor points to something above and behind the Master.

Dialogue.Line: Oh, come now, Doctor. Not that old trick.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Nonetheless, the Master turns and shoots a Primitive who was about to throw a spear at him.

Dialogue.Line: Is that what you're frightened of, Doctor? Savages hurling stones and spears?
This is just the beginning.
Maybe. Let's be on our way, shall we?
What, with this? Somewhat clapped out and broken, isn't it?
In that case, we'd better walk.
Why not?

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Primitives are still watching them.

Dialogue.Line: By order of Captain Dent, all colonists must be on the ship one hour before blast off. There can be no exceptions. Each of you can bring luggage to weigh not more than seven kilos.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Caldwell enters.

Dialogue.Line: Satisfied?
I don't arrange these things.
Did you check our ship?
Yes, I've looked over it. It's not what I call brand new.
It was obsolete when we bought it.
You know, I don't understand you people.
Anything's better than living on Earth.
You mean risking your lives coming to a place like this.
Look, that ship of ours will never make another journey. You must realise that!
I've checked the motors. They'll be all right.
Would you blast off in it?
You'll make out.
We won't and you know it! If you don't help us, we're all going to die!
I've checked every inch of the dome. There's no sign of him.
I want to see this fake Adjudicator. He's playing some game of his own and I must know what it is. Have you tried his ship?
The hatches are sealed.
Caldwell, go with Morgan. Get inside that ship. Use explosives if you have to.
Give me a moment. I've just been checking over the colonists' spaceship.
Well?
Ashe is right. It's in pretty bad shape. There's a fair chance it may blow up on the ground.
Make sure all IMC personnel are clear of the area before take off, will you?

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Dent leaves.

Dialogue.Line: Well, Caldwell? We've got a job to do.
Well?
This is it. This is the entrance.
Is it. How do we get in?
I haven't the remotest idea.
Doctor?

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Caldwell is trying to break into the Adjudicator's spaceship.

Dialogue.Line: No good. Nothing seems to shift it.
Well, we'll have to use explosives then. Hey, wait a minute. Try this.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The key that the Doctor dropped.
The doors open.

Dialogue.Line: Wait.
Look, that girl!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Caldwell and Morgan go over to Jo's prison.

The entrance to the city starts to scrape open. The Master looks up and the Doctor kicks first the pocket watch then the laser gun out of his hands as Primitives surround them and an alien comes out of the city. They are taken inside at spear point.
Jo's shouting cannot be heard outside the tube. Caldwell tries various controls on the console.

Dialogue.Line: Ah, it's no use, I can't see. Just a minute!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Caldwell pulls Jo's tube open and she falls out, coughing.

Dialogue.Line: Where is the Adjudicator?
He's not the Adjudicator, he's a fake.
We know that. Where is he?
Come on, take it easy. Where could he have got to? Do you know?
He went with the Doctor.
Where?
To the Primitive city.
Are you the leader of these people? I've come to help you.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The smaller alien turns and looks at the Master.

Dialogue.Line: Why doesn't he answer?
They don't speak. They're telepathic.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The alien leaves and the door closes.

Dialogue.Line: No, wait! What is this place?
Well, it looks like some sort of lumber room. Take a look at this frieze here. I think it might interest you.
Yes.
It's a sort of chronicle of their history, showing that their science has deteriorated into a somewhat primitive religion.
The Master's a sort of super-criminal. He can travel in time and space. He

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Dent enters.

Dialogue.Line: I'm afraid I can't help you.
I understand you've been to this Primitive city.
Yes, and we only just got out alive.
She has told me how to get there. I could take some men and hunt them down.
No, you're needed here. I'll send a squad after them once we've got rid of these people. Things are going too slowly. Get them moving.
What about this girl?
She goes with the colonists.
Look, I'm not a colonist! I've got to find the Doctor.
Put her with the rest.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Dent leaves.

Dialogue.Line: You must help me, please!
You heard what Captain Dent said. Get on that ship.
You've got to find the Master and stop him for everyone's sake.
There's nothing I can do.
Let me go. If we can find the Doctor, we may be able to stop him.
Caldwell, you were told to put her on the ship.
All right, Morgan, all right.
Caldwell, you're still under my discipline, even if you are an engineer. Now you remember that!
Who could forget it! Come on, you.
Oh, please.
You've given me enough trouble. Now get on that ship when you're told!
Please, listen to me.
Get under there. Move quick, before I change my mind.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Jo gets underneath a silver tarpaulin in the back of a buggy.

Dialogue.Line: That's absolutely fascinating. The whole story is here.
Is it? Well, perhaps you'd be kind enough to explain it to me?
Well, this city was once the center of a great civilisation.
Yes, I had rather gathered that.
By genetic engineering, they developed a super-race. That priest we saw must be a remnant of it.
You deduced all that from these pictures?
Well, not exactly. I knew it already. The files of the Time Lords are very comprehensive.
Oh, so that's more like it. You mean that you stole the information?
Well, it seemed an awful pity not to make use of it, you know? But of course that's typical of the High Council of the Time Lords. Know everything, do nothing.
Tell me, why are you so interested in the history of this planet?
Well, this super-race developed a Doomsday Weapon. it was never used.
Why not? Super-weapons usually are eventually.
Who knows? Maybe it was due to a degeneration of the life strain.
I see. And so the super race became priests of a lunatic religion worshipping machines instead of gods.
So it would seem.
Well, may I remind you that their religion embraces sacrifice, and that we are the destined victims?

Dialogue.Stage Direction: A procession is approaching.

Dialogue.Line: You're going to use this weapon?
Not unless it's absolutely necessary. Well, don't you see, Doctor? The very threat of its use could hold the galaxy to ransom.
I think you've left it a trifle late.
Doctor, you underrate me.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Master holds up a gas grenade and gas mask.

Dialogue.Line: What about me?
Try holding your breath.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The little alien priest gestures with its staff then walks towards the Doctor. The Master throws the grenade to the floor and the Primitive collapse. The Master and the Doctor make their escape.
Mary is ticking names off on a clipboard.

Dialogue.Line: Is that the last of them?
Yes, they're all on board now.
That troublemaker, Winton.
Well?
You've checked him off. I didn't see him.
He's been on board some time. He's trying to get the engines working properly.
Morgan? Where's Caldwell?
Well, he's keeping out of the way in case he has to see anything unpleasant.
He'll be all right once we've got rid of these people.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Ashe enters.

Dialogue.Line: Mary?
Ready to go?
You're sending us to our deaths.
Oh nonsense. My engineer checked your spaceship. It's sound enough.
How are you going to explain to Earth government if something happens to us?
There will be no explanation. Once you're off this planet, you're no longer my concern.
I think you're forgetting one thing, Captain Dent.
Really?
I'm the only qualified space pilot left in this colony. Suppose I refuse to blast off?
Then you can sit in your ship till you rot. Try to get out and you'll be shot on the spot.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Ashe and Mary leave.

Dialogue.Line: Suppose they do try to get out?
Put a man with a communicator on that hill overlooking the dome. If they do try to leave the ship, he can call up a security squad.
Very well.
Which way do we go now?

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Master consults a map and gestures forward.

Dialogue.Line: Wait, Doctor!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Master compares a wall marking to his map.

Dialogue.Line: Yes, we're very near to our goal now. You will soon see the most powerful weapon ever created.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The final cases of supplies are being dragged onboard.

Dialogue.Line: Is everyone aboard?
Yes.
Very well. Start your final checkout.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Ashe closes the hatch.

Dialogue.Line: Take the buggy back to the ship.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Dent rips the crop chart off the notice board.

Dialogue.Line: They've just started final check-out.
Have the guards been posted?
Yes, and the other guards have returned to the ship.
We'd better get back. Just in case.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Dent and Morgan leaves, and Winton comes out of hiding on the gantry.
An IMC guard is watching the dome and the colonist's rocket through binoculars.

Dialogue.Line: Captain Dent to Security Guard Rogers. Captain Dent to Security Guard Rogers.
Receiving you, sir.
What's happening there?
Not a thing, sir.
No attempts to leave the ship?
No, sir.
If anything happens, anything at all, I want to know at once. Captain Dent out.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Rogers is so intent on the spaceship that he doesn't notice Winton creeping up behind him until it is too late. Winton lands a good punch then they wrestle in the waterlogged clay. They trade punches, and Winton tries to drown Rogers a couple of times until he finally knocks him out.

Dialogue.Line: Shall I call up the guard again?
Yes. No. Can you get the colonist's ship on video-link?
I can try.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The viewscreen shows a close-up of Ashe wearing a headset.

Dialogue.Line: The best I can do, I'm afraid. Their equipment's pretty ropy.
Ashe, are you receiving me? Captain Dent speaking. ASHE [on viewscreen]: Yes, I'm receiving you.
What's the delay? ASHE [on viewscreen]: An electrical fault in our life support system. We're repairing it now.
How much longer? ASHE [on viewscreen]: Nearly fixed. We'll start countdown in a few moments.
Excellent. Goodbye, Ashe.
Do you think he means it?
What else can he do?

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Caldwell and Jo drive up to the buggy and boulder abandoned by the Master and the Doctor.

Dialogue.Line: Do you think they were hurt?
They must have been thrown clear.
Or else they've gone ahead on foot.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The colonist's spaceship lifts off.

Dialogue.Line: It's the colonist's spaceship! They've made it!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: KaBOOM!!!

Dialogue.Line: All those people.
And I told them the motors were all right.
Wait, Doctor. This is it.
Is it? Well, where is this super weapon of yours?
We're in the heart of it. It stretches for miles all round us. Look, let me try and explain how it works.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Master puts his map down on a console with a large circular binnacle in the centre.

Dialogue.Line: Yes.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: He presses a control and picture rises to show a view of the galaxy, which then zooms in on a star.

Dialogue.Line: Look! That, Doctor, is the sun that gives life to the planet Earth that you hold in such affection.
I do know a little basic astronomy.
Then you will know that one day that sun will burn through to its core and explode.
In about ten thousand million years time, yes.
Well, with this weapon, I could make that happen now.
That's unbelievable!
You know the Crab Nebula?
The cloud of cosmic matter that was once a sun? Of course.
That was the result of the super race testing this weapon.
Well, this it.
How do we get in?
I don't know. The Doctor and I were taken in. There must be some way of opening it.
Beats me. We'll have to find another entrance.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The door opens.

Dialogue.Line: Look.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Caldwell hides as a Primitive comes out and walks towards Jo. Caldwell hits him over the head and they get inside the city before the door closes again.

Dialogue.Line: I think it's this way. Let's try.
So, you intend to hold the universe to ransom.

Doctor, why don't you come in with me? We're both Time Lords, we're both renegades. We could be masters of the galaxy! Think of it, Doctor, absolute power! Power for good. Why, you could reign benevolently, you could end wars, suffering, disease. We could save the universe.
No, absolute power is evil.
Consider carefully, Doctor. I'm offering you a half-share in the universe.
Well?
I don't know.
We're lost.
Yes.
Morgan, where's Caldwell? None of the other miners have seen him.
One of the guards saw him leaving the dome in a space buggy. He was heading for the Primitive city.
Take a squad and get after him.
Is he worth the trouble?
Caldwell's our mining expert and don't you forget it. We can't do without him.
What about that Doctor and the fake Adjudicator?
The only one we need is Caldwell.
There will be trouble about those colonists, you know.
We offered to check their ship to make sure it was safe. They refused our help. It's all in my report.
Of course.
You must see reason, Doctor.
No, I will not join you in your absurd dreams of a galactic conquest.
Why? Why? Look at this. Look at all those planetary systems, Doctor. We could rule them all!
What for? What is the point?
The point is that one must rule or serve. That's a basic law of life. Why do you hesitate, Doctor? Surely it's not loyalty to the Time Lords, who exiled you on one insignificant planet?
You'll never understand, will you? I want to see the universe, not rule it.
Then I'm very sorry, Doctor.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Master aims his laser gun at the Doctor, and the Guardian's panel rises.

Dialogue.Line: What's happening?
Wait and see.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Guardian's throne comes out of the wall.

Dialogue.Line: What is it?
The ultimate development of life on this planet.
Why have you returned? What do you want here?
I want to restore this city and this planet to their former glory.
Don't listen to him, sir.
You have here a wonderful weapon. Why, with it you could bring good and peace to every world in the galaxy.
On the contrary. He'll bring only death and destruction.
This planet of yours could be the centre of a mighty empire! The greatest that the cosmos has ever known.
Tell me, sir, has this weapon of yours ever brought good to your planet?
Once the weapon was built, our race began to decay. The radiation from the weapon's power source poisoned the soil of our planet.
Exactly. The weapon has only brought death, and yet he wants to spread that death throughout the galaxy! Unless you destroy this weapon, sir, he will use it for evil.
No! You must be mad! Why, with this, we could control every galaxy in the cosmos! We could be gods!
You are not fit to be a god. I sense that if you have control of this weapon, you will bring only unhappiness and destruction to the entire universe.
Then die!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Master points his laser gun at the Guardian, and it disappears from his hand.

Dialogue.Line: There is a self-destructor mechanism. You will please operate it.
Not only does justice prevail on your planet, sir, but also infinite compassion.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Doctor goes to the console and touches a device. The Guardian shakes its head. Then he touches a lever and the Guardian nods, so he pulls it. The room shakes violently.

Dialogue.Line: You must leave at once, or you will be destroyed with the city.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Master leaves.

Dialogue.Line: Thank you, sir.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Primitives and other aliens are staggering towards the control room.

Dialogue.Line: Come back! You'll all be killed!
Come on! Do you want to die with them?

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Down another passage they meet -

Dialogue.Line: Jo, what are you doing here?
Looking for you.
We've got to get out of here at once. The whole place is going up! You have a map. Give it to me.
You fend for yourself.
Give him that map!
Yes, I think this is it. Come on.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Doctor leads them down a small side passage.

The group comes out of a round opening in a cliff face and runs cover. BOOM! and a ball of flame comes out of the tunnel. Another BOOM and there is a small landslide. The Master takes the opportunity to get try and get Caldwell's weapon, but fails.

Dialogue.Line: Get up! All of you, get up! Caldwell, come over here.
You've arrived just in time. Put these people under arrest.
Get back to your friends.
You don't understand. I am the Adjudicator.
You're an imposter. We don't need you.
You've got to do something, Doctor. They're going to kill you.
Morgan, you can't.
Shut up, Caldwell. If we didn't need you, you'd be over with them.
You're insane.
Drop those guns!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: A group of armed colonists are on the ridge. Morgan opens fire.

Dialogue.Line: Take cover!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Everyone takes cover behind large boulders. Bullets fly and there are casualties on both sides. The Master takes the chance to sneak away and drive off in a buggy. Morgan runs out of bullets and runs away.

Dialogue.Line: Surrender, the rest of you. You won't be killed.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The two surviving IMC men raise their hands.

Dialogue.Line: The Master. He's gone!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Jo and the Doctor get into a buggy and drive off. The Master arrives at his Tardis and watches them on the scanner, then starts the time rotor moving.

Dialogue.Line: Look!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The 'rocket' dematerialises.

Dialogue.Line: Now look, stop worrying. It was the radiation from that weapon that was poisoning the soil. Your cover crops will grow now.
Yes, well, let's hope you're right.
You know, I still don't understand why you weren't in that ship when it blew up?
Well, we knew the IMC would have to get clear before we blasted off. I hid in the dome, I knocked out the guard and let the others out.
Yes, but it took off and blew up. I saw it.
Ashe?
He took it up alone.
But he must have known!
The rocket had to take off. It was the only way that we could get IMC out of the way.
And Ashe insisted on staying on board. Yes. Yes, he would, of course.
Doctor, there's something here for you.
The Tardis!
My dear chap, this is absolutely splendid. Where did you find it?
In one of the dwellings a few miles from the dome. There was a lot of stuff there that the Primitives have stolen.
Well, I cannot tell you how grateful I am.
Doctor, what is it?
What is it? Well, er, it's, er, it's a sort of antique really, but it does have great sentimental value. Will you excuse us?
Yes, of course. Mary?

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Doctor gestures to Jo and they sneak inside the Tardis unnoticed.

Dialogue.Line: We've had a reply from Earth. They're sending an Adjudicator.
A genuine one, I hope?
This time, yes.
What about you, Caldwell? You're finished with IMC. You can never go back to Earth.
I don't think I want to.
You want to stay here?
Well, if you've a place for an out of work miner, yes.
All right, we'd be glad to have you.
Well, for a start, I can help you with your power

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Tardis dematerialises.
The Brigadier is standing where the Tardis was at the start of the story.

Dialogue.Line: Doctor, come back at once!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: So the Tardis kindly materialises in another corner.

Dialogue.Line: Come on out, Doctor.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Jo and the Doctor come out of the Tardis.

Dialogue.Line: Well, that was a short trip. You'll never get that thing working properly. Oh, you were right about that report, I'm afraid. It wasn't the Master after all.
He's talking as if we'd never been away.
As far as he's concerned, we haven't. The Tardis returned to Earth just a few seconds after it left.
What are you two talking about?
Don't try and explain Jo. He'd never understand.
